title: Online subscriptions up 40pc as shoppers seek last-minute gifts
text:
Print 
From monthly sock deliveries to cake through the letterbox, online subscription businesses are booming 
Last-minute shoppers seeking unusual presents for their friends and family are increasingly buying food, drink and clothing subscriptions , according to new data. 
Online shopping portal NotOnTheHighStreet.com said the present trend had driven up subscription sales on the site by 40pc in the past three months. 
NotOnTheHighStreet.com currently offers 159 subscription services, which range from a three-month sock subscription from Henry J Socks to The Cake Nest’s monthly cake subscription and a beer membership from Beerbods. 
One of the company’s best-selling subscription partners, The Naked Marshmallow Co , which launched on the site seven months ago, has experienced a sales increase of 160pc in the past three months. 
“People primarily buy our subscriptions as gifts for other people,” says co-founder Ollie Rendall, 25, who launched the business with partner Joseph Colson, 23, in November last year. “Everyone’s a last-minute buyer these days and an easy way to make a last-minute purchase that is unique is to get a subscription.” 
The company, which sells nine varieties of handmade marshmallow, is currently shipping up to 1,000 parcels each week, and 20pc are subscription orders. 
“I’d estimate our sales in the subscription side of the business will increase by over 3,900pc by this time next year, as we’re seeing more and more people purchase these every day,” Mr Rendall said. 
The Spicery, which also sells its wares on NotOnTheHighStreet , has seen a 40pc increase in sales of their subscription boxes over the past year and is forecasting a bigger jump at Christmas. The small business produces recipe kits and monthly spice boxes, which include a Six Month Date Night Spice Subscription. 
“Subscriptions are the gift that keeps on giving,” says founder James Ransome, 41. “People feel that they have enough stuff, so food and experiences are becoming more popular every year.” 
The Spicery, which is now 10 years old, will turn over £1.5m this year. “The majority of that is subscriptions,” Mr Ransome said. 
NotOnTheHighStreet also offers shoppers 94 different experiential gifts. There has been a 145pc increase in sales of experiences in the first six months of 2015, compared to this time last year, with the Vintage Perfume Experience, Hula Like A Pro Class, and Gin Tasting And Distillery Tour all becoming bestsellers.
